unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the best way to understand all these internet terms, right? Like, what's the deal with "VPN" and "bandwidth" and all that jazz. It can be super confusing, especially for someone who's just starting out. My Dadi asks me about these terms all the time!
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about the best way to understand all these internet terms, right? Like, what is the deal with "V-P-N" and "bandwidth" and all that jazz. It can be super confusing, especially for someone who is just starting out. My Dadi asks me about these terms all the time!

unnormalised: Firstly, don't be intimidated! Think of the internet like a giant mohalla, a neighbourhood. "IP address" is like your house number. A "website" is like a shop in that mohalla. So, a "domain name" (like google.com) is just an easier-to-remember address for that shop. Instead of "172.217.160.142," which is Google's actual IP address! See? Already making sense!
normalised: Firstly, don't be intimidated! Think of the internet like a giant mohalla, a neighborhood. "I-P address" is like your house number. A "website" is like a shop in that mohalla. So, a "domain name" (like google dot com) is just an easier to remember address for that shop. Instead of "one hundred seventy two dot two hundred seventeen dot one hundred sixty dot one hundred forty two," which is Google's actual I-P address! See? Already making sense!

unnormalised: Now, a "browser" (Chrome, Firefox, etc.) is your vehicle to get around the mohalla. "WiFi" is basically the invisible road that connects your house to the main road. If you have a faster "bandwidth" (measured in Mbps or Gbps), it's like having a wider road – more traffic (data) can flow faster! That's why your videos buffer less on a good connection.

unnormalised: Then there's "cloud storage" – think of it as a locker in the mohalla's community centre where you can store your files. "URL" is just the specific address of something within a website - like the exact location of a saree on Myntra.com. And "OTP" – One-Time Password – it’s that extra verification code you get on your phone when you’re trying to log in somewhere. Like a security guard at the entrance of a fancy building.

unnormalised: Honestly, the best way to learn is by doing. Don't be afraid to Google ("search engine" – like the mohalla's information kiosk!) terms you don't understand. Watch YouTube videos (remember bandwidth?). Ask your tech-savvy cousin or neighbour (we all have one!). Most importantly, relax, have some chai, and don't stress too much. You'll get the hang of it in no time, bhai!
